chapter.title: Creating the game world
chapter.para: A video game needs a setting, a world in which it takes place. In Scratch, you create a world by putting a costume on the stage.
In Python, you can create your setting in two different ways.
Your background is only an image or colour. Your video game characters are not able to interact with things in the background, so don't put anything too important back there. It's just set dressing.

section.title: Setting up your Pygame script
section.para: A Python script starts with the filetype, your name, and the license you want to use. Use an open source license so that your friends can improve your game and share their changes with you:

section.para: Then, you tell Python what modules you want to use. Remember, modules are like sets of Scratch blocks.
section.programlisting: import pygame # load pygame keywords import sys # let python use your file system import os # help python identify your OS
section.para: Since you'll be working a lot with this script file, it helps to give yourself sections within the file so you know where to put stuff. You do this with block comments, which are comments that only you, the programmer, sees. Create three blocks in your code.
section.programlisting:
''' Objects '''
# put Python classes and functions here
''' Setup '''
# put run-once code here
''' Main Loop '''
# put game loop here
section.para: Next, set the window size for your game. Keep in mind that not everyone has a big computer screen, so it's best to use a screen size that will fit on most people's computers.
The Pygame engine requires some basic setup before you can use it in a script. You must set the frame rate, start its internal clock, and start (init) Pygame.
section.programlisting: fps = 40 # frame rate afps = 4 # animation cycles clock = pygame.time.Clock() pygame.init()
section.para: In Scratch, to activate a script, you use the When green flag is clicked block.

textobject.para: In Scratch, the green flag block activates a script.

section.para: In Python, you don't have a green flag block, but you can use a keyword. A common keyword is main. If main is True, then the game is on. If main is not True, then the game has stopped.
Add the last line shown in this code sample to yours:
section.programlisting: fps = 40 # frame rate afps = 4 # animation cycles clock = pygame.time.Clock() pygame.init() main = True
section.para: Now you can set your background.

section.title: Setting the background
section.para: Scratch already knows what the stage is, but Python does not. Outside of Scratch, most video games just call the stage the "screen", so create a stage called screen for your game, and load a background imaage (stage.png) for it. Before you do, create a directory called images alongside of your Python script file and put a background image called stage.png into it.

section.title: Looping
section.para: Unless told otherwise, a Python script runs once and only once. Computers are very fast these days, so your Python script runs in less than a second.
